description.text:
Wasn't a fan of the paper coins that came with the base Tokaido game so I decided to take a crack at modeling a replacement and printing it with copper filament. Turned out beautifully!

You may need adjust the scale for your prints, but I found that 20mm x 20mm x 2mm to be perfect for me.

Notes:

I printed at 100% infill but by no means is that necessary. Consider adjusting your outline overlap if there are holes in the coin. I ended up using between 35-45% outline overlap w/ a .48mm Extrusion width.

title: M8 weight bracket for GoPro steady cam

description.text: I made this bracket to go under the great Steadicam by HamOp. This allows you to place a short piece of M8 threaded rod under the stabilizer to screw nuts on as weight. By moving the nut further along the rod you should be able to counter balance a Gopro Session which is not centered by default.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print this with the flat side down without supports.

Installation

An M8 nut should fit inside the square slot to screw on the existing M8 threaded rod in HamOp's design. I used a 20cm piece of M8 rod in mine but you could try to use a longer piece if you have difficulties in balancing your camera.

Design

This was a quick and dirty design in Fusion 360, no frills no nothing just a functioning piece.

author: discovercamp110

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uxLgvJQgyjQ

I saw a video about a simple DIY sand flap. I had no Idea what a sand flap was or how well it works but I decided to try to design my own and give it a try. It works surprisingly well and will certainly be used in the workings of my Filamolder 3d printer.

Take a straight piece of sand paper, fold it over length-wise and stuff it into the groove. Insert newly made bit into the chuck of your tool and spin the bit into any shape or size hole. The sand paper will adapt to the size of the hole and sand it consistently. Try to spin the bit in a circular motion around the hole for maximum sanding efficiency.

This was made in.........

description.text:
This is a simplyfied design of the very expensive SpiderHolster BlackWidow.
It is really difficult to break the screw off of the camera even with just 40€ infill (100%recommended), but i would not recommend using it for any heavy camera above 1kg of weight. Perfectly suited for casual use, or as a more comfortable way to carry your camera around while having its cord still around your neck without any tention for savety.

Next version might contain a savety system so it wont fall out under any circumstances, but this never happened to me.

Ideas and Feedback apprechiated.

author: tonihur

description.text:
OpenForge
=========
This set contains metal bar cell walls.
This was created for my Rise of the Runelords campaign, specifically for Skull Crossing in the module The Hook Mountain Massacre. This set contains tiles designed to fit with both the Smooth Edge Tile Series and Smooth Tile Series.
The full scene picture uses a mix of OpenForge tiles and Dwarven Forge tiles.
OpenForge floor tiles are designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles. Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.

This set is designed to use 6 penny 1 3/4" nails as the cell bars.
I printed in black. I painted the stone using my standard dry brushings of grey, tope and then a light grey.
The nails were "rusted" with two techniques.
On the wider walls, I used layers of brown paint, with more orange mixed in on each layer.
On the narrower wall, I used rust power I found at a model train store. starting with dark rust, rust and then light rust. This required a coat of fixative to keep it in place.

comments.text: This looks great -- really impressed with the speed that you're adding new designs -- any chance that doors are coming soon?
comments.author: CuteMaker

comments.text: I am working on doors.  I've just not been happy with any of the designs so far.  When I get something that works well, it'll get posted pretty quickly

description.text:
This is a mounting block improvement for the MK8 Extruder used for my Anet A8 with bowden setup and the extruder mounted on the frame with the mount:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2146021

The profiles of the block lead to a minimum distance to the drive gear and the counter roll that the flex filament will not bend away.

A PTFE tube must be inserted in the bore hole in the profile. The tube must be cutted to the profile.
The pneumatic fitting of the bowden can be screwed into the plastic as well as the thread rod with the nut for the spring guide.

For individual changes I have attached the part as parasolid.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I recommend PETG or ABS.

Perry Products makes really nice heavy duty suspenders with plastic clips that attach to the belt and not the pant material. title: ANET A8 HIGHT QUALITY CURA PROFILE

description.text:
Hi,

  • Last update: 2017-10-31
    => Add ABS profile. Work very well with E3D V6 and modified motor extruder. Layer are 0.12.

  • Last update: 2017-08-25
    => change: improvement of the print speed
    => test with the model 3DBenchy (see pictures)

Today this is my best setting on Cura to have an very good quality.
The only defect is the speed, is not very high.

"ANET_A8_HIGHT_QUALITY_0.1.curaprolife" is a profile settings file for Cura.
To import it in Cura you need go to "Preferences" menu => clic on "Configure Cura" => go to "Profiles" menu =W clic on "Import" button.

The STL file is just my 3D model to test the quality of print ...

Test it and give me your impression !

title: Oil change tube for emergency backup generator Honda EU20i

description.text:
Had to change the oil at my Honda EU20i Backup generator and did not like to dirty it completeley! At YouTube I saw some videos that you could use a tube to change the oil.
Because none of the tubes I got at home fitted I created an tube by my own.
The "tube" is completely solid filled and so I printed it at a Ultimaker with:
  • 0.06mm bottom and top (top and bottom can be cut off after print)
  • 0.8 wall thicknes
  • 0% Infill...
  • 0.1 layer hight
  • 150 % speed
    • Just refilled the generator and everything stayed clean!

print_settings.Notes:: This thing takes a huge amount of time to print because of all the internal detail.  I'm working on a similar one that will print faster.

description.text: I hope you enjoy this artwork that symbolizes an angel, health care, and a Stairway to Heaven (symbolism intended).

Notes:

This thing takes a huge amount of time to print because of all the internal detail. I'm working on a similar one that will print faster.

It was the usual trial and error creative process which often produces junk but sometimes unearths a gem. Although the song "Stairway to Heaven" by Led Zeppelin was not a conscious influence, it was obviously part of the inspiration.

PART OF FULL PROTON PACK BUILD

Pack: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2479141

This is the Neutron Thrower from my 3D printed Ghostbusters Proton Pack build.

The prop was made using various measurements from the gbfans.com wiki. Changes were made to have it 3D print easily, and space was made inside for all the electronics.

Inside is an arduino, which powers the lights. There is a sound board for the SFX, which is toggled be a small set of relays.

The output of the sound in the video below is connected to speakers. In the finished prop all of the wiring went down the hose and connected to power and speakers in the Proton Pack itself.

With this item I have included a parts list which should help you out, it's honestly not that hard to assemble. Pretty much all of the parts should print flat on the bed and only the Gun Body Main part will need support material. Everything else can be orientated to be printed without.

The prop is designed with holes for lenses, LEDs, switches and wires to be attached. All the holes are of a standard size which I'll list in the post printing section.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/QdX_AjVV2cY" ></iframe>
Footage of lights and sound in the thrower

Assembling the prints

Once you've printed all parts remove and support material and get yourself a good 2 part epoxy. That's all I used and mostly it'll be gluing flat surfaces together.

First glue the Gun Body Main to the Gun Body Right Plate, there are convex and concave 'keys' so you can fix it better.

The glue on the front barrel and rear handle. It's obvious which is which.

Next glue on the Switch Box Left Side, there are holes in the box and housing which should be aligned when gluing, these are for wires for your switches and lights. Then glue on the Switch Box Back, this should align with the flat edge of the Gun Body Main.

Then glue the two cylinders, the rear one should butt up to the Switch Box Back and has a hex nut designed into it. The front one goes next to the barrel.

Now glue on the 2 Grips to the handle and barrel, place where it's comfiest to hold. Just make sure to leave room for the barrel detail at the front.

On the barrel add the Front Barrel Right Box, then the Front Barrel Left Box. Then assemble the Front Wire Holders if printed in two parts and affix one to the Left Box. The other Front Wire Holder can be glued to the Front Barrel Claw and Front Barrel Ring.

The rest of the items are just cosmetic items for the Gun Body Main. Use the images provided to see where they go.

The Bottom Plate and Bottom Plate Lid can be glued together. The lid can then be screwed into place with machine screws. This is so you can have access inside the main body, if you don't need that then just glue the lid in place.

Painting, decals and details

I used spray paint to finish this off, a couple of coats of primer, then a couple of top coats. Then I used acrylic paints to weather it.

I created stickers using Adobe Illustrator based on images I've seen of them, then 2D printed those out onto vinyl printer paper, cut out and stuck on. Sticker sheet is provided in the main image reel.

You will need to obtain a clear piece of acrylic for the barrel end, the two parts where that acrylic should slot into are the same diameter. It's a standard size (can't remember what it was!) of tubing so you should find it easily.

The last parts of the detail are wires, which can be any old thing as long as it's the right size. Also there is the electronics and switches which are detailed below.

How I did it - in brief

I'm not going to go into too much detail here as it's another project in itself. But all the soulds and lights are driven from an Arduino nano, an Adafruit sound board and a small set of relays.

The Arduino drives all the flashing and steady LEDs. To create the sounds the Arduino sends voltage to a small relay, this then closes a contact which grounds a pin on the Adafruit soundboard. The soundboard was loaded with SFX which corresponded to a certain pin being grounded.

For the different states of the gun, idle and being fired. I wrote the Arduino code to run a loop program, then change it once a button was pressed and held.

The startup and shutdown sound was achieved by sending a pulse when the toggle switch was switched. The pulse then triggered the startup then shutdown sound in turn.

Electronics - basic parts

Switches are your basic two pole toggle switches.

Buttons are the single pole single throw type.

LEDs are 5mm super bright (any will do) but with 5mm LED lenses over the top.

The wire was just spare wire I had around, as long as it fits in the hole it's fine to use.

Arduino is the Arduino Nano, I bought a cheap £5 chinese knock-off from eBay but it worked perfectly with the normal Arduino code.

The soundboard is the Adafruit Audio FX (2MB), this connects to your PC like a USB drive. You then transfer over the OGG sound files named specifically to correspond with a certain pin. The soundboard outputs over headphone 3.5mm jack, so you can connect to and speaker you want.

The relays are 5V relays which come on a little circuit board. These aren't technically needed as the Arduino can talk to the Sound FX board through serial, but I didn't have time to learn how to send serial commands form the Arduino to the board. So I just used solid state outputs to achieve the same thing.

All the items are cheapish, the soundboard is the most expensive but that can always be used in other projects once completed.

Type of toggle switch used Single press momentary button used Example of LED lenses An Arduino Nano, cheap enough to leave in the project SFX board, I used Adafruit, there's probably others available Small relay board, available on Amazon

title: ImmersionRC lapRF Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Benefits include better VTX signal pickup and Bluetooth range.

Firstly there are two variations of ImmersionRC Puck Stand, the Blue one is the first version and the second Grey one is the newer revision which uses less plastic and in my opinion looks better. However my son prefers the look of V1 so hence I've uploaded both of these.

When placed in the corner of a gate at this angle the internal patch antenna covers the whole gate area and there is minimal change of a) missing a pass and b) damaging the puck due to a low pass at the centre of the gate.

For better Bluetooth range I would recommend having the lapRF on the far side of the gate. The reason for this, is the internal Bluetooth antenna is now pointing up and at you so hence much better signal than lying flat on the ground.

Parametrized Magnetic Bit Holder In 2 Parts No more misplaced bits! Sandwiched design with strong 8mm magnets. You don\'t have to glue the magnets in place (and thus spoil them) if you don\'t want to. The supplied .stl files are made to fit two rows of five magnets, put together in pairs for increased strength (20 magnets in total). All parameters can be changed in OpenSCAD. The 8mm magnets are available at dealextreme.com.
100 pack - $5.96 - http://www.dealextreme.com/details.dx/sku.13518
20 pack - $2.36 - http://www.dealextreme.com/details.dx/sku.4248 I'm working on a experimental version which clips together, needing neither glue nor screws, hopefully. We'll see how that works out... This is the first time I use OpenSCAD, how did I do?

I don\'t have a printer, yet, so these instructions are just how I imagine it coming together.
-
Put the magnets together two and two, and align them as illustrated. - They will probably sit better, and are easier to handle if they all have the same polarity.
Put the printed bottom part on a metal surface and insert the magnets. - The magnets will hold the piece in place. If the magnets don\'t want to cooperate, you can use a tiny piece of tape.
Put on the printed top. You can choose to glue the pieces together, or use screws. I think I\'d prefer to use screws and attach it directly to a wooden shelf above my workspace.
-
Alternatively you could simply superglue a magnet directly into the hole in the top part, and not print the bottom part at all. It might be necessary to make the hole a bit deeper in OpenSCAD though.
-
Be warned that these magnets are pretty strong, so be thoughtful of what you put them on.

This design is a variant of Green Lantern's lantern. It was designed to include some of the features which are found in the lantern variation available in the Injustice 2 video game, from which I drew much of the inspiration.

Assembled at 1:1 scale the lantern measures about 15.5" (~39.5cm) tall, 11.5" (~29cm) wide and 9" (~23cm) deep. The images show the lantern printed in a 1:1 scale with glow-in-the-dark filament. Opaque filaments will work as well but will not be as satisfying IMO.

The lantern has been designed to also serve as a costume prop so the handle shaft can swivel, although delicately. The shaft has holes for the handle locking pins on the inside of the lantern to allow for keeping the handle upright when used as a regular lamp.

I used green LED lights to wrap around the LED cylinder. These particular LEDs require a 12 volt power supply which does not come with the product. I used these LEDs because I already have a 12 volt battery pack which fits the power input plug (so that it can be used while being mobile). https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01HRMP46S/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 (Water-resistance IP65, 12V Waterproof Flexible LED Strip Light, 16.4ft/5m Cuttable LED Light Strips, 300 Units 3528 LEDs Lighting String, LED Tape(Green))

Nylon screws were used to assemble the lantern in addition to hot glue for the bezel pieces, shrouds, diffusers and base/LED cylinder. Note that I purposely did not design a hole/conduit for the LED cord since my primary use is anticipated to be mobile. A hole can easily be drilled in the base if so desired to accommodate the cord issue.

Because I already had the screws I do not know their type but it appears they can be found on Amazon.com. They are approximately 1" (25.4cm) long, 0.1" (~2.54cm) screw diameter and 0.23" (~5.85cm) screw head diameter. Nylon screws were used because they blend in with the glow filament but also because they can easily be cut/clipped to size. The handle pieces and the shaft couplings require shorter screws than the shaft pieces.

https://www.amazon.com/Machine-Finish-Binding-Slotted-Threads/dp/B00DD4CQCA

To properly diffuse the light from the LEDs I glued wax paper on the back of the diffusers as shown in the images.

You will need to print the following files to create the lamp shown in the images:

1 X Lantern - Base.stl
1 X Lantern - Bezels.stl (there are 4 bezels in the file)
1 X Lantern - Body.stl
2 X Lantern - Diffuser.stl
2 X Lantern - Handle Angle.stl
2 X Lantern - Handle Extension.stl
1 X Lantern - Handle Grip.stl
1 X Lantern - LED Cylinder.stl
1 X Lantern - Lid.stl
2 X Lantern - Locking Pin.stl
2 X Lantern - Shaft Coupling.stl
2 X Lantern - Shaft.stl
2 X Lantern - Shroud.stl

Join the Lantern corps now and protect your sector!!

title: Anycubic i3 Mega Filament Sensor Mounting Bracket 2.0

description.text:
I got really tired of having to mess around with the filament sensor mounted on the spool frame. It restricted how far away the spool could be from the printer and was kinda a paint to deal with in general. With the sensor mounted to the frame you can more easily change filament and move the printer around more freely if you have to and it eliminates how far away the spool can be. It mounts to the side using the two existing screws.

This is my 2.0 version of a bracket for mounting the filament sensor directly to the i3 Mega. The first version didn't work so well. This one is much easier to take the sensor on and off.

author: element3

description.text:
A Buddy that pairs with your "Dane-Elec ShareBytes" Skeleton USB Warning!
These were designed for use with a printer that can handle support material!

This skeleton was modeled in Rhino such that it pairs with a USB stick.  The model was created to correct a design flaw in the original USB stick.   
The Flaw: The USB protects the interface head by having it slide back into the skeleton-shaped casing, however when attempting to place the head into a computer port, it would often slide back into the casing instead.  
The Solution: The protrusion on the Rhino model inserts into the hole left by the USB sliding out, forcing the head to remain extended.

Simply print out with a printer that does support material well.  I printed mine on an Objet 3D Printer.  
Note: They have not been tested on a FFF printer and might do fine

This solder spool holder is designed to fit a Kester 1 pound (454g) spool. It is made from 2 identical parts that mate together (commonly known as a “hermaphroditic” part) and are secured by a single 3/4” or longer 10-32 screw and nut through the center of the spool (smaller hardware either ASE or Metric with washer would also work). I added pockets in the bottom for adhesive back felt disks from Dollar Tree, but 3/4” diameter rubber feet would work as well to limit sliding. I printed both parts at the same time on my Anet A6 using the CraftWare slicer in easy medium mode.

description.text:
The detergent dispenser door on our Frigidaire Dishwasher stopped opening during a wash. I also noticed that there wasn't a decent spring back on the dispenser door lock when you manually cycled it.

It turns out the arm which captures the spring and is activated by the detergent dispenser door solenoid had worn out.

The only replacement part they sell is the entire detergent dispenser door, which is $30 and several days shipping (part # 5304507354). I gave myself 4 hours to design, print, and test a new one before I would let myself order it. :)

Seems to work in static tests, just assembled everything and running a test wash now. This arm also controls the rinse aid dispenser, so hopefully everything still activates as it should.

A full write up is at: https://1projectaweek.com/blog/2017/7/20/practical-3d-printing

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.02MM

Infill:

22%

Notes:

Printed in Taulman Tech-G (PETG).

Supports can be tough with PETG, maybe using another material like PVA or even PLA could work. I was concerned with using PLA because of the different temperatures, so didn't go that route.

The fit is really tight, but that's on purpose. I only had to file the areas between the claws on the pin retention area. They do flex outward as the peg from the door retention cylinder is pushed in, so it should be fine. Just use even pressure and keep everything lined up.

Just a little fine sand paper to clean up mess from the supports. If I did it again I'd use some sort of dissolvable support material, PETG sticks so good that it's hard to deal with supports using the same material.
Fusion 360, a caliper and about 2 hours... Didn't take as long as I thought it would.

description.text:
I got inspired by a reddit post and decided to make my own Litecoin with a twist. I backup all my wallet data and seeds on a dedicated SD card, so I wanted a place to put it that I would remember where it is as well as not lose it.

I modelled this in Fusion360, I typically work in Solidworks but have taken a liking to Fusion recently and I'm trying to learn the ins and outs of the program, this was a fun little way to practice so I also went a step further and made two extra models for each of the mainstream hardware cryptocurrency wallets, the Ledger Nano S and the Trezor. I do not own either of these wallets so all I had to work with were the dimensions from their respective websites, so I gave a little extra tolerancing in the holes they lay in.

Printed with 7047 Tele Grey PLA. The threads came out well at 0.15mm layer height, they do require a little bit of working in for a smoother turn.

If you feel the love and enjoy this model you can tip me in LTC:

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I noticed that when I load my printer with a second spool on (my) right side, the part that hold the spool don't have good grip, which cause the spool to touch the frame and not move well.
This is because that side of the spool have much bigger diameter.
So I designed a simple hollowed wheel to fit there and reduce the diameter so the printer have better grip.
I don't know how other printers hold their spools but if you had the same problem then here's a simple solution :)

The cuvette rack can be customized to have as many holders as your printer is capable of printing. Use the customizer to specify how many holders long and how many holders wide you want your cuvette holder to be. Otherwise you can download three pre-rendered sizes (3x6, 2x3, or 2x12).

description.text:
The locking knobs on my Buzz Bike Rack were starting to fail, which seems to be a common problem with most bike racks, and I didn't feel like spending $20 for replacements that will also fail and use different keys, so I went ahead and created this knob as a replacement.

I simply customized the OpenSCAD file from the original, which I have attached.

Obviously, it doesn't lock, but I would never trust the knobs for security, anyways.

Prints without supports, and you can press in a regular M6 nut. This will fit other brands of bike racks, as long as they use an m6x1.00 thread. I printed this in PLA and it seems to stand up just fine, but it's stored inside most of the time.

author: Mentum

title: Anet A8 Filament Fan Holder for easy access

description.text:
The original model was blocking too much airflow, so I pretty much remade it. Source is in the scad file.

You can use the original screws like I did in one of the pictures, but unlike me you should print a fitting spacer.
Best is to get some m3 25mm screws to properly fix it so you can slide the fan down all the way. That should cool the big metal block on the bottom better. The heatsink is not used in this design, and not needed IMHO. Regularly clean the filament feeder from dust. Use two to four m3 20mm screws with nuts to fix the fan to part b.

Print the parts a and b turned to their flat side with 0.1mm layer height. Part c is optional, but recommended. It stops the airflow from the fan to the extruder. Helps to keep extruder temperature constant, and needed for ABS so it does not cool too fast.

For the normal variant, you'll have to sand the parts a bit and add a lubricant. There is also a loose variant that should fit easier, but might cause some rattling.

Falls ihr in Deutschland seid: Ich habe noch einige m3 25mm Schrauben übrig, und würde sie euch schicken wenn ihr mir per Paypal 70 Cent fürs Porto gebt.

Printer:

Anet A8 (Prusa i3 clone)

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

description.text:
Note: just swapped out the original version of this STL for one that's ever-so-slightly modified. The original posting had a razor-thin gap between the two pieces of the original that I'd remixed. It still printed up fine for me, but the gap was there and could be seen in the slicer. I nudged one piece .1mm closer to the other to close this gap, so it's now truly one piece.

This is just a remix of the mount for the LED strip by Reach3DCollaboration.
Original: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2106538

This remixed mount pulls the LED strip closer to the rail it's mounted to than the original part. The way I've mounted this, on the top front rail of my D-bot pointing downward toward my build plate, this remix allows the LED strip to intrude into my build space about a centimeter or so less than the original part did.

title: Prusa i3 Mk2S Camera Mount (Using standard tripod mount)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Webcam mount to monitor prints remotely whilst away from the printer. I've designed this mount to work with any standard tripod screw although the screw will need to be long enough to go through the 5mm body of the print prior to to screwing to your camera. I've used a logitech C615 webcam which has tilt, up/down adjustment so you can get the required angle.

There are 4 slots on the bracket which can be used to feed a cable tie or two through to cable manage any excess wire on your camera. My printed versions i've photoed currently use a slot that is too small but the stl file has an increased slot.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.35

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Currently printed in PLA although may redo in ABS as i have some prusa abs orange (just as I'm oct and want the colour to match.)

I printed the main bracket at 0.35 and 20% infill as i wasn't too bothered by the quality i was more concerned that it would fit and work.

The little tripod screw i used 4 perimeters and 20% infill with a 0.2 layer height. The screw seems really strong although i would take care and not over tighten in case it snap. I cannot take any responsibility for the use of these models.

I used a M3x18 screw to connect the mount to the spare hole in the x axis motor. I did find the mount was slightly loose with this screw but adding a washer to the back sorted this.

print_settings.Notes:: Flip the top part of the rack upside down to print without supports.

description.text:
Lightweight tube rack for holding 15 ml or 50 ml conical tubes (or 20 mm diameter glass tubes). Brief assembly is required, but the advantage is that the print does not require supports as a result (see post printing notes for more).

I originally made this since the larger Nalgene tube holders we have in the lab are somewhat cumbersome to carry around if you have a small number of tubes.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Flip the top part of the rack upside down to print without supports.

Assembling the rack

The top part of the rack has notches in the support legs where the middle and bottom parts fit in. I used ABS for this print and welded the parts together by pipetting an ABS/acetone mixture into the joints and letting it set overnight. Pictures show close-ups of the welds, and I recommend using a rubber band to hold the joints tight while the glue is setting.

I made the "glue" by cutting up scraps from past prints (rafts, supports, etc.) and dissolving in acetone (i.e. nail polish remover).

Close up of weld between leg and middle layer using ABS/acetone mixture Close up of weld between leg and bottom using ABS/acetone mixture Use a rubber band to hold the rack together while the ABS glue sets overnight

This bracket is designed specially for the Tevo Little Monster but I included the solidworks file if you'd like to alter it for your delta printer with a floating extruder. The purpose of this bracket is to stabilize the extruder. The original way it was strapped cause the extruder to shake and bounce around too much for my liking and the extruder was always facing to the right side which also annoyed me. The extra length of the arms produces smaller angle movements therefore a more stable extruder and now it faces to the front . I also attached a counter weight to mine which I might show later.

the printing is easy.. no over hangs. Just print upside down.

author: jaredpaquet

description.text: Ball Joint for Education purpose.

This is a spool rod with bearings. I noticed that the filament would always be tight when the extruder would feed. The basic spool rod is static so the filament spool needs to be draged around it when feeding. Using a couple of bearings I had on hand I made a spool rod that rotates easily so the extruder won't have to work so hard when feeding. It's working very well now. The filament feels very loose when feeding as it should.

I included my solidworks drawings if you'd like to modify it to whatever hardware you may have.

You should use nylon friction nuts so that you don't over tighten the bearings which would add more resistance and work against what you're trying to accomplish.

Print 2x (it's symmetrical).
For each tool you'll need:

  • 12x4 spring (12mm length, 4mm diameter),
  • two pieces of foam (steal from kitchen ;p).

Teeth in front and spring made it really reliable. It's not my first cleaner, but it's the only one which have never slide down when using (among that I've used, of course ;p).
Slotted tube with plug. The plug has a hole in the top to insert a threaded knob.

print_settings.Notes:: Infill is up to you, I just happened to be printing these with other parts, thats why the 30%

description.text:
"Press Fit" knob that the original "knob" goes into. I use press fit loosely, the idea is to gently tap it into position so that it holds tight and the grooves on the original "cut" in, securing them. Add a drop of super glue if you choose for further securing.

As suggested by Zapta: another way to insert the original knob is to use a soldering iron to heat it up while pressing it into the oversized printed knob.

Designed because I have fumble fingers anyway, and those tiny friggin knobs that come standard with the printer SUCKED. With these knobs attached I can adjust each screw with one finger, and not knock the bed completely out of whack while doing it.

print_settings.Notes:: I only used 15% infill as it doesn't need to hold much weight, and it's proximity to the wall makes it not the most stressed component anyway.

description.text:
I have my 3D printer in front of a disused door, so wanted an efficient way to store and use spools of filament. A piece of PVC pipe (20mm diameter) and this thing (x2) and it's done :-)

Easy to change/add spools, and filament flows free. If I was to do this again, I'd probably have a screw at the bottom of the "U" as well (or even exclusively) as that'd provide the most strength, but hindsight is 20/20 and this works well anyway.

Note: The screw holes are sunk for 4mm thread and 8mm head wood screws. These could be ~10% bigger if needs be!

Note 2: If you have a particularly bendy material (like PVC etc) as the rod (rather than steel or something), you might want to scale it up a little (literally in the Z axis) to ensure with some weight on it it doesn't slip out.

remixed_from.title: Ruger 1022 stock replacement part ar15 stock housing

title: Ruger 1022 stock replacement part ar15 stock housing W/storage

description.text:
Direct replacement stock for a standard Ruger 10/22.
AR15 style. It uses the standard stock mounting screw to hold it in place. The receiver locks into the housing. The standard ar15 buffer tube dimensions were used except the threading. Storage is incorporated in the tube. The tube was canted 10 degrees down. No known issued yet. It has not been printed and tested for fit yet.
20Jul17
Printed and confirmed the receiver housing fits snug and properly conforms around the factory receiver. The receiver mounting screw lines up properly. The pistol grip screw lines up properly. The pistol grip fits very snug. The receiver locks down into the stock housing and will not lift in the rear. The buffer storage tube has been sent to octopi for printing. The receiver housing was printed upside down at 45 degrees on the bed in order to fit on a 220X220 bed. A brim with supports touching the build plate was used. Wall thickness as well as top and bottom was set at 2mm. Inland PLA 1.75mm black was used. infill was set to 50% if I remember correctly although with the 2mm walls it will fill most of the model. The hole for the pistol grip is undersized to allow for drilling/melting and threading to desired size.
22Jul17
Confirmed the buffer tube fits into the receiver housing as well as a standard AR-15 adjustable stock fits on to the tube.
Find the latest updated version here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2454304

description.text: This version will also allow you to change the depth of the draws to suit your needs! There is also the option to add clips to the top and/or bottom so the racks can connect together. Make your draws as deep as you want - within the limits of your Z height. Check out my other listing for the customizable draws that go with this! (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:244335)

Customise the number and type of rows you would like. The normal, double and quad rows are 27mm high and the half row is 13.5mm. Multiply out as needed and then add 1mm to account for the final top wall thickness. The unit is 121mm wide. Select the options to have either (or both) top and bottom clips. So the RackTEST.stl would be:
(273) (13.51) 1 = 95.5mm On a Huxley (the machine I have) the maximum number of normal height rows are 4. On a Mendel that would increase to 7. YMMV on other machines :-) Then print out all the draws you need.

author: martin_au

title: BLTouch Fan Mount for Anycubic Kossel Plus Linear
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
BLTouch Fan Mount

This is a fan mount for the BLTouch onto Anycubic Kossel Plus Linear. I designed this after not being able to get other mounts to work how I would have liked them to mount. I designed this not only to be closer to the extruder nozzle but also to have cool air being pulled across the BLTouch so I don't have to worry about any heat problems as well.

Hardware Setup

To connect your BLTouch to your TriGorilla you first need to get a longer ribbon cable, I bought a kit off of amazon for, and you need to wire it to the following pins. The servo connector is the 3 wide connector pin comes like the follow setup (S) (+) (-), you must re-arrange the positive and negative pins to be (S) (-) (+) to connect to the Servo 0 port on your TriGorilla PCB.

Next the limit switch that is the flat two plug connector with a white and black wire, this must be plugged into your Z- on your board. The TriGorilla PCB for the limit switch have the following pin assignment (+5) (G) (S) so you must orient the plug so the black wire so that it connects to the middle ground pin and the white wire to the Sensor pin which is the pin towards the inside of the your TriGorilla PCB. I can not stress this enough, I had this backwards at first, and all it would do when issuing the G29 command would to shove the nozzle further down into my build plate and off to the side.

Firmware Setup

Here is what I had to change to get the BLTouch to work with my Anycubic Firmware, which I'm running RC_1.1.0. All the changes were made in Configuration.h in Arduino.

1st. Need to update the Motherboard from 33 to 43 so you can control the BLTouch with g-codes
#define MOTHERBOARD 43

2nd. Under your Delta Settings you need to make sure you have your printable radius calculated correctly. I have a 240mm build plate but I have my printable radius set to 116 which would be 232mm:
#define DELTA_PRINTABLE_RADIUS 116

3rd. Under Z Probe Options, you will need to uncomment BLTouch so it will go from this:
//#define BLTOUCH
to this:
#define BLTOUCH

Then you will need to comment out Z probe allen key, so it will go from this:
#define Z_PROBE_ALLEN_KEY
to this:
//#define Z_PROBE_ALLEN_KEY

Then you need to scroll down a little further so you have to set the X and Y probe offset from the extruder for your BLTOUCH. Here are mysettings:

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER +35     // X offset: -left  +right  [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER +10   // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
#define Z_PRO BE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0  // Z offset: -below +above  [the nozzle]

I have done my best to design my mount so the BLTouch is exactly 8.2mm higher from my nozzle, HOWEVER different nozzles will change this position! So before you try printing anything you will need to check this, which I will cover further below.

4th. Next move to the Auto Bed Leveling section. You need to have bilinear bed leveling defined in the code with the following lines as follows:

//#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_3POINT
//#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_LINEAR
#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_BILINEAR

And then you need to check your boundary probe settings. I set mine to be my printable radius - 50, this might be overkill, but it's working so I don't want to mess with it again. I have set mine to the following below:

// Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).
#define DELTA_PROBEABLE_RADIUS (DELTA_PRINTABLE_RADIUS - 50)
#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION -(DELTA_PROBEABLE_RADIUS)
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION DELTA_PROBEABLE_RADIUS
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION -(DELTA_PROBEABLE_RADIUS)
#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION DELTA_PROBEABLE_RADIUS
Calibration

THIS IS CRITICAL TO THE SETUP! Before you go to print with your new BLTouch you will need to do the following through Pronterface! After you have uploaded all your firmware changes to your Kossel Plus, you will need to check the distances! So in Pronterface, first issue the g28 g-code command. Next, the first time you go to run the g29, I would go ahead a click the RESET button, this will open a confirmation window asking you to confirm if you want to reset the printer, leave this open the first time you test out you BLTouch!!!! If it starts to hit area's off the build plate you can confirm the reset and stop your printer instantly!!!

Assuming the BLTouch works perfectly, and you hit all your points, then you should zero back your x and y with g0x0y0by doing the paper test again to check the nozzle distance to the build plate. If you have to move the Z-Axis to a negative number such as -1.3, then you need to adjust the following configuration in your Configuration.h:
#define Z_PRO BE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -1.3 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]
At the same time if you go to do the paper test, and your nozzle is barely touching the build plate with the Z-Axis at +1.3 then you would need to update your Configuration.h parameter to the following:
#define Z_PRO BE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER +1.3 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

Seriously double check this several times to be sure!!!

Start G-Code Settings

So in your Slicing software, you will need to modify your Start G-Code settings for your printer. I'm using Cura 2.6.2 because that has given me the best print results so far, but this should work in any slicing software. You need to add the following command after g28 like the following:

G28 ;Home
G29 ;Auto Bed Level BLTouch
G1 X0 Y0 Z15.0 F6000 ;Move the platform down 15mm
;Prime the extruder
G92 E0
G1 F200 E3
G92 E0

At this point you should be done, and you should have a working BLTouch with you Anycubic Kossel Plus 3D Printer.

If you have any question please feel free to leave a comment or send me a message. I'm very new to 3D Printing, about two weeks into it now, but it's been a learning experience! Hopefully this will help people out getting their BLTouch to work with their Anycubic Kossel Printers!!!

Special Thanks

First I wanted to that RDMotors for helping me get my printer even printing, getting things to adhere to my build plate was an adventure.

Second I wanted to thank JamesWhite, he has an adjustable mount design for the Anycubic Kossel as well and he also published his firmware to helped others throughout his comment section which enabled me to get my BLTouch working!

Traced a similar part's profile on paper, scanned with document scanner (Xsane), used Inkscape to create a path, imported path into FreeCAD.

In FreeCAD I extruded the trace to desired thickness, added 3 pockets, and threw some fillets on for polish.

FreeCAD is an opensource full 3D parametric modeling application. It can be found at https://freecadweb.org/

Version 2: Changed handle through hole to 4/5 through and made counter sink for door mounting screw deeper.

Version 3: Added small surface 90-deg normal to mounting surface to prevent part from freely rotating on door.

FT 2020 Kossel Delta Spool Holder

This spool holder is designed to mount to 2020/2040 extrusions. The shaft is made from the left over carbon rod that was used to build the delta arms in the FT Delta kit. The spool holder allows the spool to be placed directly behind the extruder and places just enough tension on the spool to keep it from unwinding and binding on itself.

Edit: The rod used in the design has a 5mm O.D./3mm I.D. And a length of 6" should be adequate, but double check your placement/application BEFORE shortening the rod.

Edit: Added two renderings that should be helpful as a guide for assembly.

-"2020SpoolHolder1" is the two rod holder brackets
-"2020SpoolHolder2" is the two pieces used to make ONE hub. You need two of these hubs to support one spool.

Note: For the hub assembly, place the hub (largest of the two parts) on the carbon rod. Next slide the hub spacer (smallest of the two parts) behind the hub and, using CA glue, bond both pieces together. This completes the hub assembly. If you feel you do not need the spacer, it is optional and not necessary to make a working spool holder.

Problems:
When I tried to upgrade the Anet A8 printer, I forgot to turn off the power supply and make the main controller chip damaged.
Solved:
Replace the chip and re-flash it.

Steps:
1st:
Solder out the damaged chip and replace it. Take out your power supply, it will be used to power your controller board when re-flash the firmware.

2nd:
If you already have an AVR ISP programmer, so skip this step.
If you have an Arduino around, follow this link: http://make.kosakalab.com/make/electronic-work/avrisp-mk2/uno-r3_avrisp-mk2_en/
And if you don't have any ISP programmer or Arduino board, skip all of this post. :v or find one.

3rd:
Install AVR Studio. Then open Tool>Device Programming. Plug in ISP programmer that you have from 1st step. Connect ISP connect pins from ISP programmer to Controller board. Pinout in the above picture.
Programming parameters:
Fuse: 0xFD;0xDA;0xD6 (from up to down in programming fuse tab, VERY IMPORTANCE!!!)
Memory: Find the attached files.

MY MISTAKE:
I've flashed wrong fuse bytes, the AVR Atmega1284P chip cannot be recognized by ISP programmer. I must supply a clock source to XTAL1 pin of chip while re-flash the fuse byte. Pls cmt if you had this problem!

Finish! Goodluck
If have any problem, pls cmt!

description.text:
There's very little info online regarding how to wire a filament runout sensor properly on "compound motherboards". Schematics barely exist, are outdated, or simply doesnt have data you seek. So i hope to help by keeping it simple.
This applies to motherboards out there like my OSOYOO MKS Base v1.5 board and my Hictop red MPX .3
Made this to work with regular end-stops micro switches.
(This may work with regular ramp boards, but i dont have one to look closely and or personally confirm, all my boards are the "compound, all in one" motherboards)

Hardware needed:
Endstop microswitch with pigtail connector
Four 3mm x 1.5mm magnets
M3 x 5mm screw
M3 Nut

Software side of things:
This applies to Marlin!! Specifically the latest version as of 7/20/17 (v1.1.4)
There's 3 changes that must take place:
(1) Enable filament runout sensor on Config.h
(2) Enable advanced pause and adjust values to what you want your machine to do
(3) Make sure the right pin is used by firmware

The changes are explained in the text file attached. If i paste code here, thingiverse would make a mess of it, and look all weird.

This works even when using Octoprint.

UPDATED 8-2-2017
uploaded 3mm version as well

Printer:

Hypercube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

12%

Notes:

Lid is held together with two pairs of 3mm x 1.5mm magnets.

This is intentionally designed to float between the extruder motor (bowden setup) and the filament roll as seen on the pic attached. I didn't want to make any brackets because it will be more cumbersome for my setup. For me it causes no extra drag. Im sure someone with direct drive could mount it. I will leave up to you to design your own bracket solution, using a longer screw would suffice to attach this.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gXBFtTEYkG3

So lets say you have an awesome lightsaber thats awesome sauce!!

But now what? When you are not wielding a saber made of light you need an just as awesome place to keep it. I ran into this problem as well and I have come up with a solution.

I give you the force side agnostic galactic light saber wall holder! "lasercut edition"

This can be cut and used in different ways as I have left options available. The base plate can be used by itself just on your desk or the back plate can be affixed to a wall via holes that you add for screws or even velcro quick strips. The hooks are sized to average lightsaber size (yours may differ) so feel free to size it accordingly. Additionally the holes for the hook will need to be manually added to allow for better placement of the hooks for your saber. The middle hollow plates are optional to allow for lighting, cut and stack as many as you need for the led's that you are using.

All holes for screws are M4 size and can be countersunk.

I am going to keep refining this so stay tuned!

description.text: A small claw that has holes to be sewn into fursuit or other character gloves. can be printed with a thick wall or solid if preferred. Print in ABS for the strongest claw, but other types will work. If you print small, a small drilling tool with be needed. or a very sharp needle.

This is my huxlyified version of geoffd123's pen holder.
The changes I made were to move the mounting points to the correct places for he huxleys x-carriage, change the elastic band fittings to a simple hook rather than a 3mm bolt and change the design to use square nuts (I find these behave better than the regular ones when trapped inside the part).

• Tweak SCAD to suit the pens you plan to use, and print.
  • assemble top and bottom parts with two 3mm machine screws and nuts
  • add elastic band
  • add 2 macine screws and nuts to the mounting holes on the top part as they are on the print head.
  • remove the printhead and replace it with the new pen holder
  • start plotting!
    • Things to be aware of...
  • The diameter I selected turned out to be too narrow. This was fixed with a 10mm drill.
  • The support structures I print to support the hooks are way too fragile and one of htem colapsed mid-way through printing. Amazingly it still worked, but you might want to re-think the support before printing your own.
  • The pen is not quite in the same place as the print nozzel so you loose about 20mm in the y axis.
    • Required Parts PartQty Elastics Bands 2 M3 20mm Bolts 4 M3 Washers 4 M3 Nuts 4

description.text:
UPDATE: 01/04/2018
After months of continuous testing and feedback, I have developed 3 variations of the original design, each one suitable for different hand sizes!

This adapter was developed by request of my friend Rami Wehbe , who wanted a way to play Zelda: Breath of the wild using only his left hand; as he lost the ability to control his right hand due to a cerebrovascular accident.

The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild has a complex control scheme, and the shape of the included Joy-Con grip doesn't help at all. So, I decided to make a customized grip that would help in this situation.

This current design was the result of almost a week of research and lots of failed prototypes, as I had to ensure that it would be easy to print, lightweight and practical. After testing that it works properly, we decided to share it, so that it can be of help to other gamers in a similar situation. Please bear in mind that this design was optimized for use with the left hand. Although it's possible to use it with the right hand, some actions might be difficult to perform. For right-handed users, I strongly recommend this design

Demonstration video:
https://youtu.be/5AEry5VSmhY

Watch Rami play Breath of the Wild single-handedly!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q-tTyJ8kJAo
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SMbqbP4VH6Y

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro 2016

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I have tested this model in PLA, and it works perfectly. Print time takes approximately 1 hour and a half.

comments.text: Hi, had this printed and the joycons do not fit at all. Anyone else had this issue?
comments.author: katiesigh

comments.text: In your case, my suggestion would be to use a file to sand down the rails, which will allow you to fit the controllers.
comments.author: katiesigh

comments.text:
Your comment is actually the second time someone has told me about this issue... But, in the other case, the adapter couldn't "hold" the controllers properly and they constantly slipped out of it. Seems that this is caused by poor calibration of the machine used to print it, which affect the dimensions of the printed part.
In this design, the dimensions of the rail need to be printed as close to the target measures as possible, because these parts are the ones in charge of holding the controllers. Too small and they won't fit, too big and they will be loose.

comments.text: Hi Vexelius, I was looking for reviews on Nintendo Switch controller for people with handicap when I came across Rami's YouTube video that led me to this website. My 9 years old son who is an avid gamer since he was 4 has a weak left hand/arm that he is unable to use in gaming. It amazes me how he can play with regular controllers using only one hand. Obviously it's challenging to be really competitive and play all games/levels that require enhanced coordination with only one hand. Some times he gets frustrated, which breaks my heart!.... He loves Mario games! So far I have been on the fence about buying Nintendo Switch as I wasn't quite sure if he'd be happy or sad that he can't play his favorite games. This has given me hope! Two questions: Q1. I know it has been really helpful for handicapped adults, have you heard any feedback on kids using this adapter with ease? Q2. I don't know enough about how and where to get this printed, can you please provide some guidance? Thank you!

description.text:
I went through 4 design fittings, 2 were whole pieces, 1 was split to be glued together (structurally was weaker but prints were cleaner), and the 4th version had a better sizing all around requiring less material. A GoPro nut is needed for this guy, i robbed one off of my older mounts.

DO KEEP IN MIND

The Rode PSA1 is a scissor style boom arm, this bracket i have designed is made to only fit when it is in its smallest collapsed form. If it fits loose then widen the scissor arm a tad, too much may end up snapping it. I might make a version that will only fit on 1 of the arms to resolve this issue altogether, being sturdy was my priority.

If you are printing in PLA then i highly recommend more than 5% infill, maybe even heat treating too.

title: Lithophane Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: A lithophane box that holds 4 lithophanes and a 9 led light in the center.

Printer:

CR-10, Prusa MkII

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

15% for the box parts, 100% for the lithophanes

Instructions and Requirements Part 1.

The only purchase you will need for this project is a 9 led light and three AAA batteries. You should be able to find both of these at Walmart.

Instructions and Requirements Part 2. Jpeg to Lithophane.

I used this website http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ to convert images into an stl file. Before converting selected images to stl files, make sure that the images are a size of 632x600 pixels. It is very important that the images selected are this size, as the lithophanes will not fit after printing.

When uploading your selected images to http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/, click on the Settings icon on top of the page then on Model Settings and change the Maximum Size (MM) to 150. Next, click on Image Settings. You should then see settings for positive and negative image at the near top of the page. Make sure you have the positive image setting selected. When you are sure that all of your settings are correct, click on the Model icon on top of the page to start converting your image to an stl file.

Instructions and Requirements 3. Printing

Printing the top of the lithophane box requires support material. I printed the lithophanes flat on the print surface, with a speed of 10mm/s with a layer height of .1mm hot end temp of 220 degrees bed temp 45 degrees with 100% infill.

title: Willys MB simplified cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The forefather of the Jeep is the Willys MB. Developed in the 1940s this 4x4-truck was supposed to be small, relatively cheap and produced in large quantities. The soldiers loved the vehicle for it's endurance and agility.

This tiny model, made from seven layers of plywood sports the distinctive features like the nine-slot steel grille, the spare tire and the gasoline canister mounted on the back. I decided against adding more details (like the steering wheel) because it would have resulted in to fragile elements. The glue-up is still a little tricky, but the parts are cut real fast.

I used 6.3 mm beech plywood and 5 mm beech rods for the axles. The parts were cut on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. The orientation of the body parts is specifically chosen to get the perfect alternating pattern of the plywood. A closer nesting would have been possible if the orientation wouldn't matter. The same applies for using a laser cutter.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Toys/Cars for more toy cars designs.

I added a set of 3-dimensional parts, but due to the lack of a 3d-printer I did not try it out. The stl of the complete model is for three dimensional viewing purpose only. It will not print well on a fdm printer!

The design was done completely in 2D using Illustrator. I used SketchUp to create a 3d model before wasting some material. So I could spot errors in the design and get an overall feeling for the model.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L1j-Kq0TiWk
Here you can see the alternating colors of the plywood. I took my four prototypes to get the final drawing set. On a cnc not that of a problem.

title: HF210 FPV Racing Drone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
WOW.

OVER 4000 VIEWS AND NEARLY 600 DOWNLOADS! I NEVER EXPECTED ONE OF MY DESIGNS TO PROVE SO POPULAR :) IF YOU HAVE ENJOYED THIS 'THING' AND WANT TO SUPPORT MY FUTURE DRONE DESIGNS, PLEASE CLICK ON THE BLUE 'TIP DESIGNER' BUTTON ON THE LEFT OF YOUR SCREEN. THANK YOU KINDLY IN ADVANCE, ZACK.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9TSEU6fhrRQ

Non-Commercial:
You do not have permission to print and sell this frame, either as a whole or as individual components. You do have permission to print and fly this frame for your own use. If you do so, please share your thoughts and results with me here: http://hxlmes.co.nz/contact

If you would like to share your build or flight videos on social media such as Instagram and Twitter, please use the hashtags #HXLMESFlight and #HF210 in your post. If you are on YouTube, share your flight videos with me at youtube.com/HXLMES.

Please pay attention and respect the creative commons license these files are released under. This means the files are available for personal use only. For those without a printer, all the parts will soon be available for purchase at: www.hxlmes.co.nz

Key features:

  • 2 printed components
  • Unibody design
  • Extremely strong/lightweight
  • Print with your preferred material
  • Print on 200mm x 200mm bed
  • 210mm size frame
  • Fits 4” propellers
  • Total print time (both parts) approx 7 hours with Prusa 0.25mm profile and 22% cubic infill
  • M3 x 16/19mm slots for motors
  • 30.5mm hole spacing for FC/PDB (max. stack height 30mm)
  • Top-mount battery for good COG and prevent damage in crashes
  • Built-in motor guards allow motor cooling
  • All wiring and connections hidden for a super clean build
  • No support material needed!
  • No standoffs required!

Weight:

  • Frame only: 104g
  • RTF: 488g

Instructions:

Feel free to contact me with any questions: http://hxlmes.co.nz/contact

Print one of each of the components (2 total)

Required hardware:

  • 2x M3 x 10mm machine screws
  • 4x M3 nuts
  • 1x #29 elastic band
  • 1x zip tie & heat shrink

Attach the screws and nuts to either side of the top cover as shown in image 8. Fasten the zip tie near the front of the top cover by looping it through the slots (image 9), the heat shrink slides over both the zip tie and antenna (image 10) from your Rx to keep it upright and away from the props (no need to shrink it down as long as it is a tight fit). To see how to attach the top cover to the lower frame using the elastic band, check out this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uww9_MAOlg8

Print settings:

  • Layer Height: 0.25mm
  • Walls: 3
  • Top Layers: 5
  • Bottom Layers: 4
  • Infill: 22%

I use a cubic infill as I've found it provides a great balance of strength and weight, as well as a faster print time.

Don’t forget to share this ‘Thing’ on all your social media / forums. To stay up to date with the continual developments, including new part releases and upgrades, follow me using the links below:

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/hxlmes_/
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/HXLMES
Twitter: https://twitter.com/HxlmesDesign

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

22%

Notes:

I'm using the MK2S, Flashforge PLA, and cubic infill.

Assembly

Refer to images for component placement. Feel free to contact me with any questions: http://hxlmes.co.nz/contact

See the list below for an example of the parts I've used in this build.

PLEASE NOTE: This frame is set up for building using a 4-in-1 ESC, with a standard 30.5mm x M3 mounting hole pattern. The channels in the arms of the frame are large enough to accommodate the motor wires plus soldered connections for lengthening them (as I was required to do on my build).

Flight controller: http://www.getfpv.com/betaflight-f3-flight-controller.html
ESC: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/High-Quality-Favourite-FVT-LittleBee-Spring-20Ax4-20A-4-in-1-BB2-Blheli-S-2-4S/32790176012.html
Rx: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/High-Quality-FrSky-XM-2-4G-16CH-Telemetry-Receiver-For-RC-Toys-Models/32773305239.html
Motors: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/4-Pieces-EMAX-brushless-motor-2204-MT2204-II-kv2300-CW-CCW-mini-multicopter-250-330-quadcopter/32683503759.html
FPV camera: https://www.amazon.com/Foxeer-HS1190-600TVL-Sensitive-Bracket/dp/B01N3R85HC
VTx: https://www.amazon.com/Team-BlackSheep-TBS-UNIFY-PRO/dp/B01BFQ81EE

Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions about this parts list or the build!
